text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Editorial changes were made throughout to update IRM, statutory, web, titles, and organizational references.

Revised the title of IRM 11.3.6.1 to Program Scope to properly reﬂect the information communicated in this subsection. Included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles:
a. IRM
, Background - Added information about the circumstances surrounding the seals and certiﬁcations process. Information from prior section
, Background, was incorporated into this new subsection. b. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities about the seals and certiﬁcations process. c. IRM
, Roles and Responsibilities - This IRM applies to all IRS employees and contractors. d. IRM
, Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used terms and acronyms pertaining to the seals and certiﬁcation process. e. IRM
, Related Resources - Added related resources applicable to the seals process.

Added new (3) to IRM 11.3.6.4.2, Preparation of “Blue Ribbon” Certiﬁcations, to provide sample language of certiﬁcation to be presented in court when the Form 2866 accompanies the Form 4340. All other subsequent paragraphs were renumbered, accordingly.

Changed title of IRM 11.3.6.6 from State Department Certiﬁcations to Seal of the Department of Treasury. Updated information in this section to reﬂect that any request for certiﬁcation to affix the Seal of the Department of the Treasury should be coordinated through the Disclosure office.
Updated address and fax numbers in IRM 11.3.6.7, U.S. Residency Certiﬁcations.

Revised IRM 11.3.6.10(3) and the Note to clarify that the date on the Form 3050 represents the date that the certiﬁcation was completed and is used to attest that the information on the Form is true and

Table of Contents
) Purpose: This IRM section governs the use of seals and certiﬁcations as described in
Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) §
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison, closure and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (
) Program Owner: The GLDS office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the vicewide Disclosure policy. (
) IRC Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §
authorizes seals of office and
governs the use of seals and describes and illustrates the (
) The seals of office are used to authenticate originals or copies of Internal Revenue Service (IRS) records. (
CFR §
authorizes the Commissioner to designate persons may issue certiﬁcations as necessary to administer internal revenue laws regulations. (
) Delegation Order
, (found in IRM
), designates the persons who may affix the official seal of the IRS to any certiﬁcate or attestation required authenticate IRS documents and records. Delegation Order
, (found in IRM
), designates the persons who may affix the official seal of the Department of Treasury. (
) Each seal of the office will be in the custody of the officer for whose office it was established. It may be placed in any location convenient to its use. (

) Certiﬁcations may be issued only for records in the custody of the certifying officer. Note: The certifying officer cannot attest to something he/she has not observed. Therefore, it is usually inappropriate to rely upon the oral “assurance” of other IRS personnel that the document being certiﬁed is a true and copy of the original.
IRC Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §7514 authorizes seals of office and 26 §301.7514-1 governs the use of seals and describes and illustrates the seals.

) No seal will be affixed to material to be published in the Federal Register. (

11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

• 28 USC §1733(b) • Rule 44 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure • Rule 27 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure (1) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) is used by all IRS employees to help comply with the seals and certiﬁcations provisions of IRC §7514. (1) The following is a list of the terms and acronyms that are used in this IRM section: Terms and Deﬁnitions Term Deﬁnition Certiﬁcation a certiﬁcate attesting the truth of some statement or event Seal an embossed emblem, ﬁgure, symbol, word, letter, etc., used as attestation or evidence of authenticity Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition CFR Code of Federal Regulations GLDS Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards HQ Headquarters IDRS Integrated Data Retrieval System IRC Internal Revenue Code IRM Internal Revenue Manual PGLD Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure SFR Substitute for Return USC United States Code
This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) is used by all IRS employees to help comply with the seals and certiﬁcations provisions of IRC §7514.
The following is a list of the terms and acronyms that are used in this IRM section:

symbol, word, letter, etc., used as attestation or evidence of authenticity Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition CFR Code of Federal Regulations GLDS Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards HQ Headquarters IDRS Integrated Data Retrieval System IRC Internal Revenue Code IRM Internal Revenue Manual PGLD Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure SFR Substitute for Return
Procedure Title Guidance IRM 1.17.7.7.1 IRS Symbol, Logo, Discusses official use and Official Seal of the IRS seal and provides a graphic of the official IRS and Treasury Department seals.
Any member of the public may request certiﬁcation of a document. However, neither the Freedom of Information Act,
USC §
, nor the Privacy Act
USC §

a, requires that certiﬁcations be provided to a requester. Requests for certiﬁcation should ordinarily be sent to the office having custody of the records (i.e., Headquarters, area, territory, or campus). Form

, Request Copy of Tax Return, provides for the certiﬁcation option when returns are provided pursuant to that process. There are no fees charged when certiﬁcation is provided for another govern- ment agency. The two formal processes for certiﬁcation (discussed in IRM
and
), require a completed Form
, Certiﬁcate of Official Record. Use the formal processes for certiﬁcation is not mandatory. The informal process for certiﬁcation is called the “ink stamp method” which used in lieu of a Form

This method is permissible in jurisdictions both the U.S. Attorney and the governing District Courts ﬁnd this practice suitable. The ink stamp method should include: identiﬁcation of the number pages, the name, title, and signature of the certifying officer with the date signed, and the acceptable wording shown below.
Example: Acceptable wording for an inked stamp is:
IRS REPRODUCTION, per IRC §6103(p)(2)(C).”
“This photocopy has the same legal status as if it were the original.”
) With the exception of the circumstances described in IRM
) and (

), providing documents in lieu of testimony, the ink stamp method is the type of certiﬁcation that will be done for non-government requesters. If other situations arise that would appear to require one of the formal processes for certiﬁcation, they should be discussed with the Disclosure Policy & Program Operations Manager in Disclosure Headquarters (HQ). (
) Form
, Certiﬁcate of Official Record, is available for authenticating originals or copies of records. (
) Offices preparing a large volume of certiﬁcations for use by other agencies may, at their option, employ suitable continuous feed printout paper instead printed copies of Form

) For documents where “blue ribbon” certiﬁcation is not requested, the Form
is prepared as follows. (

) Immediately after the phrase “I certify that the annexed:” insert a statement similar to the following: • Is the original. . . or • Is a true copy of. . . or • Is an exact transcript of. . . or • Is an exact transcript of an electronically ﬁled return (without document) (

) Immediately after the statement shown above, insert the identiﬁcation of record, which may include items such as: • The form number and title of the record • The name of the taxpayer • The date of the record • The name of the signer of the record • The type of tax and tax year involved and/or • Any other feature by which the record would normally be identiﬁed Note: Electronically ﬁled returns may consist of the electronic record as well as paper form containing the signature (e.g., Form

, U.S. Individual Tax Transmittal for an IRS e-ﬁle Return). In such cases, the complete cannot be certiﬁed without including all pertinent parts of the return. However, should it be impossible to locate the Form
or its is permissible to certify the electronic transcript (TRPRT) alone as long is correctly described as in (
) above. Since the transcript alone cannot certiﬁed as the “return,” the following language is to be used in certifying electronic return with Form
: “......is a true copy of an electronically ﬁled Form
, U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, with Form
, U.S. Individual Income Tax for an IRS e-ﬁle Return.”

appearing on an original Form 2866. Entries should be arranged in substan- tially the same sequence and layout as on Form 2866. The original and copies should be processed in a similar manner as provided below for certiﬁcations
The use of blue paper for Form 2866 is not mandatory. Electronic versions of Form 2866 may be printed on blue paper as long as they meet the standards
For documents where “blue ribbon” certiﬁcation is not requested, the 2866 is prepared as follows.
Immediately after the phrase “I certify that the annexed:” insert a similar to the following:

Paper substitutes for returns submitted as “dummy” returns used to an assessment on the taxpayer’s module are not “returns,” but rather consti- tute return information. The certiﬁcation of a Substitute for Return (SFR) should state something to the effect that it is “A Substitute For Return package prepared by IRS.” The substitute for return may not be a traditional tax return, but may consist of one or more documents that together support the assessment of tax. In these cases, it will be especially important to ap- propriately identify the document(s) being certiﬁed on the Form
See (
) and (
) below. In contrast, returns prepared by the IRS under the authority of IRC §
(b) are considered “returns.” The distinction between an SFR and an IRC §
(b) return is that the Form
used for the SFR includes only the taxpayer’s identifying information, while an IRC §
(b) return is prepared by the IRS with additional information such as income, deductions and tax liability that constitutes a valid tax return. IRC §
(b) returns should be certiﬁed as returns, although language should be included in the certiﬁcation indicating that IRS prepared the return pursuant to authority granted by IRC §

Paper substitutes for returns submitted as “dummy” returns used to establish an assessment on the taxpayer’s module are not “returns,” but rather consti- tute return information. The certiﬁcation of a Substitute for Return (SFR)

Note: Paper substitutes for returns submitted as “dummy” returns used to an assessment on the taxpayer’s module are not “returns,” but rather tute return information. The certiﬁcation of a Substitute for Return (SFR) should state something to the effect that it is “A Substitute For Return package prepared by IRS.” The substitute for return may not be a tax return, but may consist of one or more documents that together support the assessment of tax. In these cases, it will be especially important to ap- propriately identify the document(s) being certiﬁed on the Form

) Material requested with respect to documents submitted as a return but do not constitute a valid return should be identiﬁed as being a true copy of a document “purported to be an income tax return,” or “submitted to the IRS,” similar wording. (
) Identiﬁcations should generally be brief and include only those details necessary to identify the record. They should not attempt to characterize or comment upon the record. (
) Any attachments should be similarly identiﬁed. The identiﬁcation should end with the phrase “. . . consisting of . . . pages.” (

) There should be no punctuation after the last word of the identiﬁcation “pages”). Instead, a line should be drawn from the last word to the right (generally about one inch from the edge of the paper) and then diagonally to point just above the ﬁrst “u” in the phrase “under the custody of this office.” (
) The name and title of the certifying officer is placed beneath the phrase “By direction of the Secretary of the Treasury,” leaving sufficient space for the signature. (
) Separate certiﬁcations are made for each type of document. Example: An administrative ﬁle must be certiﬁed separately from the tax return.
Example: An administrative ﬁle must be certiﬁed separately from the tax return.
Note: Make separate certiﬁcations for each taxable year involved unless the document pertains to multiple years.
Original and amended returns for the same tax year are certiﬁed together.
Disclosure of Official (
) After signature, the dates are inserted. A gummed or self-sticking notarial is placed in the lower left corner of Form
For all certiﬁcations used in IRS tax (Title

) cases, i.e., cases involving enforcement of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) alone or in combination with other chapters of the States Code, the seal cannot be pre-embossed and placed on the Form It must be “raised” through the Form

For certiﬁcations that will be in non-tax cases, i.e., cases that do not involve the enforcement of the IRC, pre-embossed seal may be used as long as the consumer has agreed to accept the pre-embossed seal. The stamp of the office of the certifying is the stamp to be used for the embossing. (
) Records being certiﬁed are stapled behind the Form
, along the upper corner, taking care not to obliterate any portions of the record. (
) If the individual requesting certiﬁed documents and the court where they be introduced both agree, ink stamped certiﬁcations may be provided. (

) Each office issuing certiﬁcations must retain a ﬁle copy of the certiﬁcation, together with any appropriate background information. of (
) The copy of the certiﬁcation must show all entries that appear on the except the seal of office. (

) The background ﬁle should identify the intended recipient (taxpayer or for whom the certiﬁcation was prepared. This information may be entered the copies of the certiﬁcation or in a history sheet, or it may be documented including relevant correspondence in the ﬁle. (
) The background ﬁle should identify by name and title the employee respon- sible for requesting the certiﬁcation, preparing the package and retrieving records. (
) The information required by (
) and (

) above must be readily available to official signing the certiﬁcation and must be easily obtainable in the event of some future inquiry. As this information will appear only on the IRS retained copies or background ﬁles, it can be typed, handwritten or rubber stamped. (

) Requests for certiﬁcation may arise in connection with various activities ﬁles are maintained. The copy of the certiﬁcation and any background tion would generally be incorporated with the existing ﬁles. A separate ﬁle certiﬁcations does not need to be maintained. (
) A copy of the Form
may be provided to another office or another having an interest in the case. (

) Every certiﬁcation of records inherently involves an intended disclosure of official records. The certiﬁcation ﬁle should include any necessary analysis the request and evaluation of the records to ensure that disclosures are properly authorized. (

) Personnel preparing certiﬁcations should make certain that all evidentiary quirements are met. Copies of records must portray the originals accurately and be free of any distortions, ﬂaws or illegible markings not present in the original. (

) Certiﬁcations must conform to the standards of the court whenever in court is expected. Example: Certain entity information must be redacted when providing for certain bankruptcy and Tax Court proceedings. The description of certiﬁed document on Form
must address the required alterations. (
) Records being certiﬁed must be known to originate in official IRS ﬁles. (
) Occasionally, individuals will request certiﬁcation of their copy of a return or
11.3.6.5 (04-30-2009) Standards for Certiﬁcations

Certain entity information must be redacted when providing certiﬁcations for certain bankruptcy and Tax Court proceedings. The description of the certiﬁed document on Form 2866 must address the required redactions/ alterations.

) Occasionally, individuals will request certiﬁcation of their copy of a return or will request certiﬁcation of a document in their possession allegedly obtained previ- ously from the IRS. Such requests must be refused. Instead, the requester may be told how to request certiﬁcation of an original record in the IRS’s custody.
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

) Any office may certify the authenticity of any IRS record, even though the record may have originated in another office. The office issuing the must have physical possession of the record and be aware how the record came into its possession. (
) When a record to be certiﬁed is located in another office, it is generally able to transfer the request to the office having possession of the record, rather than transfer the record. (

) The officer certifying the authenticity of a record is responsible for reviewing the ﬁle, comparing the copy with the original, and verifying its accuracy and authenticity before signing. However, where written audit trails (with appropri- ate attestations by IRS personnel) are available that provide the same of assurance, possession of the original may be waived. These situations should be rare (e.g., an instance where voluminous active ﬁles need to be certiﬁed, and the custodial office has no one with certiﬁcation authority). (
) The U.S. Department of the Treasury has speciﬁc requirements for use of Treasury Seal. Per Delegation Order
, found in IRM

, only the Department Disclosure personnel are authorized to affix the seal of the Department of Treasury Treasury. If an IRS record needs to be authenticated with the Department of the Treasury seal, contact Disclosure to coordinate the certiﬁcation. (

) As proof of residence in the United States and of entitlement to certain under tax treaties, an applicant must provide a U.S. Government certiﬁcation U.S. residency to a foreign withholding agent. The IRS requires submission Form
, Application for United States Residency Certiﬁcation, to obtain a certiﬁcate of residency (Form
) from the Philadelphia Accounts Manage- ment Center. Send mis-routed Forms
with a check or money order to: Internal Revenue Service Philadelphia Campus

The U.S. Department of the Treasury has speciﬁc requirements for use of the Treasury Seal. Per Delegation Order 11-3, found in IRM 1.2.49.4, only Disclosure personnel are authorized to affix the seal of the Department of the Treasury. If an IRS record needs to be authenticated with the Department of the Treasury seal, contact Disclosure to coordinate the certiﬁcation.

As proof of residence in the United States and of entitlement to certain beneﬁts under tax treaties, an applicant must provide a U.S. Government certiﬁcation of U.S. residency to a foreign withholding agent. The IRS requires submission of Form
, Application for United States Residency Certiﬁcation, to obtain a certiﬁcate of residency (Form
) from the Philadelphia Accounts Manage- ment Center. Send mis-routed Forms
with a check or money order to:

In the past, special arrangements had been made with some countries, involving individualized certiﬁcation language or the signing of forms issued by other governments. All such forms should be referred to the Foreign Certiﬁca
tion Unit at the Philadelphia Campus.
Certiﬁcations
page (
) IRC §

)(C) provides that any reproduction of any return, document, other matter made in accordance with that section will have the same legal status as the original. This IRC section further requires that any such tion shall, if properly authenticated, be admissible in evidence in any judicial administrative proceeding as if it were the original, whether or not the original is in existence. (
) IRC §
provides that judicial notice shall be taken of the seals. of Seals (
) Certain applicants, usually the Department of Justice, occasionally request tiﬁcations from the IRS for use in court proceedings that conﬁrm a lack of to Lack records. Form
, Certiﬁcate of Lack of Record, should be used for this purpose, using the embossed seal procedures detailed in IRM

). When questions concerning the use of this type of certiﬁcation cannot be resolved by a Disclosure employee, they must elevate the matter to Policy & Program Operations , Disclosure HQ, following proper procedures. (
) To prepare a Form

for the lack of a return when a substitute for return has been ﬁled or an Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) transcript that an SFR has been established, local procedures can be developed. However, one acceptable approach is to insert in the Form
space for “Description of Record(s) Sought,” the following: “Form
that was duly completed, executed, and ﬁled by the taxpayer.” Note: Changing the “Description of Record(s) Sought” to “Form
duly completed, executed, and ﬁled by the taxpayer” when completing the cation of lack of record, clearly certiﬁes that no Form
was prepared ﬁled by the taxpayer. (
) The Form
should only cover the speciﬁc years being certiﬁed as a lack record. The Form
must be dated and signed on the date it is created in order to properly attest to the information provided. The date the Form
signed represents the date that the certiﬁcation was completed and is attesting, with the Signature, that the information on the Form is true and correct. Note: Form
must avoid any inference that the lack of record determination extends beyond any cut-off period when responding to ex parte court under IRC §
) or IRC §
)(C). These orders have a cut-off date for disclosure of information coming to the IRS. See IRM Disclosure to Federal Agencies for Administration of Non-tax Criminal (
) Title
USC §
prohibits the fraudulent or wrongful certiﬁcation of documents and the knowing use, sale or transfer of any documents fraudu- of lently or wrongfully certiﬁed. Violators are subject to a ﬁne and/or

Certain applicants, usually the Department of Justice, occasionally request cer- tiﬁcations from the IRS for use in court proceedings that conﬁrm a lack of records. Form 3050, Certiﬁcate of Lack of Record, should be used for this purpose, using the embossed seal procedures detailed in IRM 11.3.6.4.1(12). When questions concerning the use of this type of certiﬁcation cannot be resolved by a Disclosure employee, they must elevate the matter to Disclosure Policy & Program Operations , Disclosure HQ, following proper procedures.

Form 3050 must avoid any inference that the lack of record determination extends beyond any cut-off period when responding to ex parte court orders under IRC §6103(i)(1) or IRC §6103(i)(7)(C). These orders have a speciﬁed cut-off date for disclosure of information coming to the IRS. See IRM 11.3.28, Disclosure to Federal Agencies for Administration of Non-tax Criminal Laws.
Title
USC §

prohibits the fraudulent or wrongful certiﬁcation of documents and the knowing use, sale or transfer of any documents fraudu- lently or wrongfully certiﬁed. Violators are subject to a ﬁne and/or imprisonment of up to ﬁve years.
